activities.name: Random key
activities.description: Generate random Fernet key. Fernet guarantees that a message encrypted using it cannot be manipulated or read without the key. Fernet is an implementation of symmetric (also known as “secret key”) authenticated cryptography
activities.example:
>>> # Generate a random key
>>> generate_random_key()
b'AYv6ZPVgnrUtHDbGZqAopRyAo9r0_UKrA2Rm3K_NjIo='
activities.snippet:
# Generate a random key
generate_random_key()

activities.name: Encrypt text
activities.description: Encrypt text with (Fernet) key,

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to be encrypted.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Path where key is stored.

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a random key
>>> key = generate_random_key()
>>> # Encrypt text with this key
>>> encrypt_text_with_key('Sample text', key)
b'gAAAAABd8lpG8fNqcj5eXrPPHlx4KeCm-1TgX3jkyhStMfIlgGImIa-qaINZAj8XcxPcG8iu84iT56b_qAW9c5qpe7btUFhtxQ=='
activities.snippet:
# Generate a random key
key = generate_random_key()
# Encrypt text with this key
encrypt_text_with_key('Sample text', key)

activities.name: Decrypt text
activities.description: Dexrypt bytes-like object to string with (Fernet) key

parameters.name: encrypted_text
parameters.description: Text to be encrypted.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Path where key is stored.

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a random key
>>> key = generate_random_key()
>>> # Encrypt text with generated key
>>> encrypted_text = encrypt_text_with_key('Sample text', key)
>>> # Decrypt text with same key
>>> decrypt_text_with_key(encrypted_text, key)
'Sample text'
activities.snippet:
# Generate a random key
key = generate_random_key()
# Encrypt text with generated key
encrypted_text = encrypt_text_with_key('Sample text', key)
# Decrypt text with same key
decrypt_text_with_key(encrypted_text, key)

activities.name: Encrypt file
activities.description: Encrypt file with (Fernet) key. Note that file will be unusable unless unlocked with the same key.

parameters.name: input_file
parameters.description: Full path to file to be encrypted.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Path where key is stored.

parameters.name: output_file
parameters.description: Output path. Default is the same directory with "_encrypted" added to the name

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a random key
>>> key = generate_random_key()
>>> # Create a textfile to illustrate file encryption
>>> textfile_path = make_textfile()
>>> # Encrypt the textfile
>>> encrypt_file_with_key(textfile_path, key=key)
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\generated_textfile_encrypted.txt'
activities.snippet:
# Generate a random key
key = generate_random_key()
# Create a textfile to illustrate file encryption
textfile_path = make_textfile()
# Encrypt the textfile
encrypt_file_with_key(textfile_path, key=key)

activities.name: Decrypt file
activities.description: Decrypts file with (Fernet) key

parameters.name: input_file
parameters.description: Bytes-like file to be decrypted.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Path where key is stored.

parameters.name: output_file
parameters.description: Outputfile, make sure to give this the same extension as basefile before encryption. Default is the same directory with "_decrypted" added to the name

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a random key
>>> key = generate_random_key()
>>> # Create a textfile to encrypt file
>>> textfile_path = make_textfile()
>>> # Encrypt the textfile
>>> encrypted_textfile = encrypt_file_with_key(textfile_path, key=key)
>>> # Decrypt the newly encrypted file
>>> decrypt_file_with_key(encrypted_textfile, key=key)
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\generated_textfile_encrypted_decrypted.txt'
activities.snippet:
# Generate a random key
key = generate_random_key()
# Create a textfile to encrypt file
textfile_path = make_textfile()
# Encrypt the textfile
encrypted_textfile = encrypt_file_with_key(textfile_path, key=key)
# Decrypt the newly encrypted file
decrypt_file_with_key(encrypted_textfile, key=key)

activities.name: Key from password
activities.description: Generate key based on password and salt. If both password and salt are known the key can be regenerated.

parameters.name: password
parameters.description: Passwords

parameters.name: salt
parameters.description: Salt to generate key in combination with password. Default value is the hostname. Take in to account that hostname is necessary to generate key, e.g. when files are encrypted with salt 'A' and password 'B', both elements are necessary to decrypt files.

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a key from password
>>> key = generate_key_from_password(password='Sample password')
b'7jGGF5w_xyI0CIZGCmLlnNyUvFpNvIUY08JCHopgAmm8='
activities.snippet:
# Generate a key from password
key = generate_key_from_password(password='Sample password')

activities.name: Hash from file
activities.description: Generate hash from file

parameters.name: file
parameters.description: File to hash

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: Method for hashing, choose between 'md5', 'sha256' and 'blake2b'. Note that different methods generate different hashes. Default method is 'md5'.

parameters.name: buffer_size
parameters.description: Buffer size for reading file in chunks, default value is 64kb

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a text file to illustrate hash
>>> textfile_path = make_textfile()
>>> # Get hash from textfile
>>> generate_hash_from_file(textfile_path)
'1ba249ca5931f3c85fe44d354c2f274d'
activities.snippet:
# Generate a text file to illustrate hash
textfile_path = make_textfile()
# Get hash from textfile
generate_hash_from_file(textfile_path)

activities.name: Hash from text
activities.description: Generate hash from text

parameters.name: file
parameters.description: Text to hash

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: Method for hashing, choose between 'md5', 'sha256' and 'blake2b'. Note that different methods generate different hashes. Default method is 'md5'.

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a hast from text
>>> generate_hash_from_text('Sample text')
'1ba249ca5931f3c85fe44d354c2f274d'
activities.snippet:
# Generate a hast from text
generate_hash_from_text('Sample text')

activities.name: Random number
activities.description: Random numbers can be integers (not a fractional number) or a float (fractional number).

parameters.description: Upper limit for random number

parameters.name: fractional

7

parameters.description: Add a locale to generate popular name for selected locale.

activities.name: Random address
activities.description: Generates a random address. Specifying locale changes random locations and streetnames based on locale.

parameters.name: locale
parameters.description: Add a locale to generate popular name for selected locale.

activities.name: Random beep
activities.description: Generates a random beep, only works on Windows

parameters.name: max_duration
parameters.description: Maximum random duration in miliseconds. Default value is 2 miliseconds

parameters.name: max_frequency
parameters.description: Maximum random frequency in Hz. Default value is 5000 Hz.

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a random beep
>>> generate_random_beep()
activities.snippet:
# Generate a random beep
generate_random_beep()

activities.name: Random date
activities.description: Generates a random date.

parameters.name: days_in_past
parameters.description: Days in the past for which oldest random date is generated, default is 1000 days

parameters.name: formatting
parameters.description: Formatting of the dates, replace with 'None' to get raw datetime format. e.g. format='Current month is %B' generates 'Current month is Januari' and format='%m/%d/%Y %I:%M' generates format 01/01/1900 00:00.

activities.example:
>>> # Generate a random date
>>> generate_random_date()
01/01/2020 13:37'
activities.snippet:
# Generate a random date
generate_random_date()

activities.name: Generate unique identifier
activities.description: Generates a random UUID4 (universally unique identifier). While the probability that a UUID will be duplicated is not zero, it is close enough to zero to be negligible.
activities.example:
>>> # Generate unique identifier
>>> generate_unique_identifier()
'd72fd7ea-d682-4f78-8ca1-0ed34142a992'
activities.snippet:
# Generate unique identifier
generate_unique_identifier()

activities.function_call: Chrome(load_images=True, headless=False, incognito=False, disable_extension=False, maximize_window=True, focus_window=True)
activities.name: Open Chrome Browser
activities.description: Open the Chrome Browser with the Selenium webdriver. Canb be used to automate manipulations in the browser.Different elements can be found as:

parameters.name: load_images
parameters.description: Do not load images (bool). This could speed up loading pages

parameters.name: headless
parameters.description: Run headless, this means running without a visible window (bool)

parameters.name: incognito
parameters.description: Run in incognito mode

parameters.name: disable_extension
parameters.description: Disable extensions

activities.example:
>>> # Open the browser
>>> browser = Chrome()
>>> # Go to a website
>>> browser.get('https://automagica.com')
>>> # Close browser
>>> browser.quit()
activities.snippet:
# Open the browser
browser = Chrome()
# Go to a website
browser.get('https://automagica.com')
# Close browser
browser.quit()

activities.name: Save all images
activities.description: Save all images on current page in the Browser

parameters.name: output_path
parameters.description: Path where images can be saved. Default value is home directory.

activities.example:
>>> # Open the browser
>>> browser = Chrome()
>>> # Go to a website
>>> browser.get('https://www.nytimes.com/')
>>> # Save all images
>>> browser.save_all_images()
>>> browser.quit()
['C:\\Users\\<username>\\image1.png', 'C:\\Users\\<username>\\image2.jpg', 'C:\\Users\\<username>\\image4.gif']
activities.snippet:
# Open the browser
browser = Chrome()
# Go to a website
browser.get('https://www.nytimes.com/')
# Save all images
browser.save_all_images()
browser.quit()

activities.name: Find elements by text
activities.description: Find all elements by their text. Text does not need to match exactly, part of text is enough.
activities.example:
>>> # Open the browser
>>> browser = Chrome()
>>> # Go to a website
>>> browser.get('https://nytimes.com')
>>> # Find elements by text
>>> browser.find_elements_by_text('world')
[webelement1, webelement2 , .. ]
activities.snippet:
# Open the browser
browser = Chrome()
# Go to a website
browser.get('https://nytimes.com')
# Find elements by text
browser.find_elements_by_text('world')

# Find elements by text

activities.name: Highlight element
activities.description: Highlight elements in yellow in the browser

>>> browser.highlight(first_link)

activities.name: Set credential
activities.description: Add a credential which stores credentials locally and securely. All parameters should be Unicode text.

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Username for which credential will be added.

parameters.name: password
parameters.description: Password to add

parameters.name: system
parameters.description: Name of the system for which credentials are stored. Extra safety measure and method for keeping passwords for similar usernames on different applications a part. Highly recommended to change default value.

activities.example: >>> set_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')
activities.snippet: set_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')

activities.name: Delete credential
activities.description: Delete a locally stored credential. All parameters should be Unicode text.

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Username for which credential (username + password) will be deleted.

parameters.name: system
parameters.description: Name of the system for which password will be deleted.

activities.example:
>>> set_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')
>>> delete_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')
activities.snippet:
set_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')
delete_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')

activities.name: Get credential
activities.description: Get a locally stored redential. All parameters should be Unicode text.

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Username to get password for.

parameters.name: system
parameters.description: Name of the system for which credentials are retreived.

activities.example:
>>> set_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')
>>> get_credential('SampleUsername')
'SamplePassword'
activities.snippet:
set_credential('SampleUsername', 'SamplePassword')
get_credential('SampleUsername')

activities.name: Create FTP connection
activities.description: Can be used to automate activites for FTP

parameters.name: server
parameters.description: Name of the server

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Username

parameters.name: password
parameters.description: Password

activities.example:
>>> # This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
>>> # Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
>>> ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
activities.snippet:
# This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
# Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')

activities.name: Download file
activities.description: Downloads a file from FTP server. Connection needs to be established first.

parameters.name: input_path
parameters.description: Path to the file on the FPT server to download

parameters.name: output_path
parameters.description: Destination path for downloaded files. Default is the same directory with "_downloaded" added to the name

activities.return: Path to output file as string
activities.example:
>>> # This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
>>> # Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
>>> ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
>>> # Download Rebex public file 'readme.txt'
>>> ftp.download_file('readme.txt')
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\readme_downloaded.txt'
activities.snippet:
# This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
# Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
# Download Rebex public file 'readme.txt'
ftp.download_file('readme.txt')

activities.name: Upload file
activities.description: Upload file to FTP server

parameters.name: from_path
parameters.description: Path file that will be uploaded

parameters.name: to_path
parameters.description: Destination path to upload.

activities.return: Patht to uploaded file as string
activities.example:
>>> # This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
>>> # Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
>>> ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
>>> # Create a .txt file for illustration
>>> textfile = make_textfile()
>>> # Upload file to FTP test server
>>> # Not that this might result in a persmission error for public FPT's
>>> ftp.upload_file(textfile)
activities.snippet:
# This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
# Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
# Create a .txt file for illustration
textfile = make_textfile()
# Upload file to FTP test server
# Not that this might result in a persmission error for public FPT's
ftp.upload_file(textfile)

activities.name: List FTP files
activities.description: Generate a list of all the files in the FTP directory

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path to list files from. Default is the main directory

activities.return: Prints list of all files and directories
activities.example:
>>> # This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.

10-27-15  03:46PM       <DIR>          pub
04-08-14  03:09PM                  403 readme.txt
'226 Transfer complete.'

# This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
# Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
# Show all files in main directory
ftp.enumerate_files()

activities.name: Check FTP directory
activities.description: Check if FTP directory exists

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path to check on existence. Default is main directory

activities.example:
>>> # This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
>>> # Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
>>> ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
>>> # Check if 'pub' folder exists in main directory
>>> ftp.directory_exists('\\pub')
True
activities.snippet:
# This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
# Take caution uploading and downloading from this server as it is public
ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
# Check if 'pub' folder exists in main directory
ftp.directory_exists('\\pub')

activities.name: Create FTP directory
activities.description: Create a FTP directory. Note that sufficient permissions are present

parameters.name: directory_name
parameters.description: Name of the new directory, should be a string e.g. 'my_directory'

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path to parent directory where to make new directory. Default is main directory

activities.return: Boolean if creation was succesful (True) or failed (False)
activities.example:
>>> # This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
>>> # Trying to create a directory will most likely fail due to permission
>>> ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
>>> # Create directory
>>> ftp.create_directory('brand_new_directory')      
False
activities.snippet:
# This example uses the Rebex FPT test server.
# Trying to create a directory will most likely fail due to permission
ftp = FTP('test.rebex.net', 'demo', 'password')
# Create directory
ftp.create_directory('brand_new_directory')

activities.name: Press key
activities.description: Press and release an entered key. Make sure your keyboard is on US layout (standard QWERTY).If you are using this on Mac Os you might need to grant acces to your terminal application. (Security Preferences > Security & Privacy > Privacy > Accessibility)

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Key to press

activities.example:
>>> # Open notepad to illustrate typing
>>> run('notepad.exe')
>>> # Press some keys
>>> press_key('a')
>>> press_key('enter')
>>> press_key('b')
>>> press_key('enter')
>>> press_key('c')
activities.snippet:
# Open notepad to illustrate typing
run('notepad.exe')
# Press some keys
press_key('a')
press_key('enter')
press_key('b')
press_key('enter')
press_key('c')

activities.name: Press key combination
activities.description: Press a combination of two or three keys simultaneously. Make sure your keyboard is on US layout (standard QWERTY).

parameters.name: first_key
parameters.description: First key to press

parameters.name: second_key
parameters.description: Second key to press

parameters.name: third_key
parameters.description: Third key to press, this is optional.

parameters.name: force_pyautogui
parameters.description: Set parameter to true to force the use of pyautogui. This could help when certain keypresses do not work correctly.

activities.example:
>>> # Open notepad to illustrate typing
>>> run('notepad.exe')
>>> # Press 'ctrl + s' to prompt save window 
>>> press_key_combination('ctrl', 's')
activities.snippet:
# Open notepad to illustrate typing
run('notepad.exe')
# Press 'ctrl + s' to prompt save window 
press_key_combination('ctrl', 's')

activities.name: Type text and characters
activities.description: Simulate keystrokes. If an element ID is specified, text will be typed in a specific field or element based on the element ID (vision) by the recorder.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text in string format to type. Note that you can only press single character keys. Special keys like ":", "F1",... can not be part of the text argument.

parameters.name: element_id
parameters.description: ID of the element. To define an element and attach an ID one can use the Automagica recorder. The recorder uses vision to detect an element and can be invoked with the recorder() function.

parameters.name: clear
parameters.description: Attempts to clear the element before typing using hotkeys. Be cautious when using this method as a vision mismatch could result in deleting unwanted data. Default value is False

parameters.name: interval_seconds
parameters.description: Time in seconds between two keystrokes. Defautl value is 0.01 seconds.

activities.example:
>>> # Open notepad to illustrate typing
>>> run('notepad.exe')
>>> # Type a story
>>> type_text('Why was the robot mad? \n They kept pushing his buttons!')
activities.snippet:
# Open notepad to illustrate typing
run('notepad.exe')
# Type a story
type_text('Why was the robot mad? \n They kept pushing his buttons!')

activities.name: Get mouse coordinates
activities.description: Get the x and y pixel coordinates of current mouse position.These coordinates represent the absolute pixel position of the mouse on the computer screen. The x-coördinate starts on the left side and increases going right. The y-coördinate increases going down.

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: Delay in seconds before capturing mouse position.

parameters.name: to_clipboard
parameters.description: Put the coordinates in the clipboard e.g. 'x=1, y=1'

activities.example:
>>> get_mouse_position()
(314, 271)
activities.snippet: get_mouse_position()

activities.name: Display mouse position
activities.description: Displays mouse position in an overlay. Refreshes every two seconds. Can be used to find mouse position of element on the screen.These coordinates represent the absolute pixel position of the mouse on the computer screen. The x-coördinate starts on the left side and increases going right. The y-coördinate increases going down.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: Duration to show overlay.

activities.example: >>> display_mouse_position()
activities.snippet: display_mouse_position()

activities.name: Mouse click
activities.description: Clicks on an element based on the element ID (vision) or pixel position determined by x and y coordinates.

parameters.name: element_id
parameters.description: ID of the element. To define an element and attach an ID one can use the Automagica recorder. The recorder uses vision to detect an element and can be invoked with the recorder() function.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X-coördinate

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y-coördinate

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: Delay between clicks in seconds, standard value is 100 ms.

activities.example:
>>> # Click on a vision element, use the recorder() function to define elements
>>> recorder()
>>> # Use the element ID found by the recorder, e.g.: click(element_id='ABCD')
>>> # Alternatively, click on coordinates
>>> click(x=100, y=100)
activities.snippet:
# Click on a vision element, use the recorder() function to define elements
recorder()
# Use the element ID found by the recorder, e.g.: click(element_id='ABCD')
# Alternatively, click on coordinates
click(x=100, y=100)

parameters.description: X-coördinate

activities.name: Move mouse
activities.description: Moves te pointer to an element based on the element ID (vision) or pixel position determined by x and y coordinates x-y position.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: ID of the element. To define an element and attach an ID one can use the Automagica recorder. The recorder uses vision to detect an element and can be invoked with the recorder() function.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X-coördinate

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y-coördinate

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: Delay between movements in seconds, standard value is 100 ms.

activities.example:
>>> # Use recorder to find an element ID
>>> recorder()
>>> # Move mouse to element or coordinates
>>> move_mouse_to(x=100, y=100)
>>> move_mouse_to(element_id='123exampleID')
activities.snippet:
# Use recorder to find an element ID
recorder()
# Move mouse to element or coordinates
move_mouse_to(x=100, y=100)
move_mouse_to(element_id='123exampleID')

activities.name: Move mouse relative
activities.description: Moves the mouse an x- and y- distance relative to its current pixel position.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X-coördinate

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y-coördinate

activities.example:
>>> move_mouse_to(x=100, y=100)
>>> wait(1)
>>> move_mouse_relative(x=10, y=10)
activities.snippet:
move_mouse_to(x=100, y=100)
wait(1)
move_mouse_relative(x=10, y=10)

activities.name: Drag mouse
activities.description: Drags mouse to an element based on the element ID (vision) or pixel position determined by x and y coordinates x-y position.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: ID of the element. To define an element and attach an ID one can use the Automagica recorder. The recorder uses vision to detect an element and can be invoked with the recorder() function.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X-coördinate

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y-coördinate

parameters.name: delay
parameters.description: Delay between movements in seconds, standard value is 100 ms.

parameters.name: button
parameters.description: Button to hold while dragging. Options are 'left', 'middle' and 'right'. Standard value is 'left'.

activities.example:
>>> # Use the recorder to find an element ID to drag mouse to
>>> recorder()
>>> # Drag mouse to this element
>>> drag_mouse_to(element_id='123exampleID')
>>> # Alternatively, use coordinates
>>> move_mouse_to(x=100, y=100)
>>> drag_mouse_to(x=1, y=1)
activities.snippet:
# Use the recorder to find an element ID to drag mouse to
recorder()
# Drag mouse to this element
drag_mouse_to(element_id='123exampleID')
# Alternatively, use coordinates
move_mouse_to(x=100, y=100)
drag_mouse_to(x=1, y=1)

activities.name: Random screen snippet
activities.description: Take a random square snippet from the current screen. Mainly for testing and/or development purposes.

parameters.name: size
parameters.description: Size (width and height) in pixels for square snippet. Default value is 100 pixels

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path where snippet will be saved. Default value is home directory with name 'random_screensnippet.jpg'

activities.example:
>>> random_screen_snippet()
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\random_screensnippet.jpg'
activities.snippet: random_screen_snippet()

activities.name: Screenshot
activities.description: Take a screenshot of current screen.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path to save screenshot. Default value is home directory with name 'screenshot.jpg'.

activities.example:
>>> take_screenshot
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\screenshot.jpg'
activities.snippet: take_screenshot

activities.name: Click on image
activities.description: This function searches the screen for a match with template image and clicks directly in the middle. Note that this only finds exact matches.For a more advanced and robust vision detection method see Automagica AI functionality.

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: Path to the template image.

activities.return: True if image was found and clicked on. False if template image was not found.
activities.example:
>>> # Create a random snippet from current screen
>>> # This is for illustration and can be replaced by template
>>> snippet = random_screen_snippet(size=10)
>>> # Click on the snippet
>>> click_image(snippet)
activities.snippet:
# Create a random snippet from current screen
# This is for illustration and can be replaced by template
snippet = random_screen_snippet(size=10)
# Click on the snippet
click_image(snippet)

activities.name: List files in folder
activities.description: List all files in a folder (and subfolders)Checks all folders and subfolders for files. This could take some time for large repositories.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path of the folder to retreive files from. Default folder is the home directory.

parameters.name: extension
parameters.description: Optional filter on certain extensions, for example 'pptx', 'exe,' xlsx', 'txt', .. Default value is no filter.

parameters.name: show_full_path
parameters.description: Set this to True to show full path, False will only show file or dirname. Default is True

activities.return: List of files with their full path
activities.example:
>>> # List all files in the homedirectory
>>> get_files_in_folder()
['C:\\Users\\<username>\\file1.jpg', 'C:\\Users\\<username>\\file2.txt', ... ]
activities.snippet:
# List all files in the homedirectory
get_files_in_folder()

activities.name: Create folder
activities.description: Creates new folder at the given path.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Full path of folder that will be created. If no path is specified a folder called 'new_folder' will be made in home directory. If this folder already exists 8 random characters will be added to the name.

activities.return: Path to new folder as string
activities.example:
>>> # Create folder in the home directory
>>> create_folder()
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\new_folder'
activities.snippet:
# Create folder in the home directory
create_folder()

activities.name: Rename folder
activities.description: Rename a folder

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Full path of folder that will be renamed

parameters.name: new_name
parameters.description: New name of the folder e.g. 'new_folder'. By default folder will be renamed to original folder name with '_renamed' added to the folder name.

activities.return: Path to renamed folder as a string. None if folder could not be renamed.
activities.example:
>>> # Make new folder in home directory for illustration
>>> testfolder = create_folder()
>>> # Rename the folder
>>> rename_folder(testfolder, new_name='testfolder_brand_new_name')
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\testfolder_brand_new_name'
activities.snippet:
# Make new folder in home directory for illustration
testfolder = create_folder()
# Rename the folder
rename_folder(testfolder, new_name='testfolder_brand_new_name')

activities.name: Open a folder
activities.description: Open a folder with the default explorer.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Full path of folder that will be opened. Default value is the home directory

activities.return: Path to opend folder as a string
activities.example:
>>> # Make new folder in home directory for illustration
>>> testfolder = create_folder()
>>> # Open folder
>>> show_folder(testfolder)
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\new_folder'
activities.snippet:
# Make new folder in home directory for illustration
testfolder = create_folder()
# Open folder
show_folder(testfolder)

activities.name: Move a folder
activities.description: Moves a folder from one place to another.If the new location already contains a folder with the same name, a random 4 character uid is added to the name.

parameters.name: fom_path
parameters.description: Full path to the source location of the folder

parameters.name: new_path
parameters.description: Full path to the destination location of the folder.

activities.return: Path to new location of folder as a string. None if folder could not be moved.
activities.example:
>>> # Make new folder in home directory for illustration
>>> # If no new_folder exists in home dir this will be called new_folder
>>> testfolder = create_folder()
>>> # Make a second new folder
>>> # Since new_folder already exists this folder will get a random id added (in this case abc1)
>>> testfolder_2 = create_folder()
>>> # Move testfolder in testfolder_2
>>> move_folder(testfolder, testfolder_2)
'C:\\Users\\<username>\\new_folder_abc1\\new_folder'
activities.snippet:
# Make new folder in home directory for illustration
# If no new_folder exists in home dir this will be called new_folder
testfolder = create_folder()
# Make a second new folder
# Since new_folder already exists this folder will get a random id added (in this case abc1)
testfolder_2 = create_folder()
# Move testfolder in testfolder_2
move_folder(testfolder, testfolder_2)

activities.name: Remove folder
activities.description: Remove a folder including all subfolders and files. For the function to work optimal, all files and subfolders in the main targetfolder should be closed.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Full path to the folder that will be deleted

parameters.name: allow_root
parameters.description: Allow paths with an arbitrary length of 10 characters or shorter to be deleted. Default value is False.

activities.return: Path to deleted folder as a string
activities.example:
>>> # Make new folder in home directory for illustration
>>> testfolder = create_folder()
>>> # Check if folder exists
>>> print( folder_exists(testfolder) ) # Should print True
>>> # Remove folder
>>> remove_folder(testfolder)
>>> # Check again if folder exists
>>> folder_exists(testfolder)
False
activities.snippet:
# Make new folder in home directory for illustration
testfolder = create_folder()
# Check if folder exists
print( folder_exists(testfolder) ) # Should print True
# Remove folder
remove_folder(testfolder)
# Check again if folder exists
folder_exists(testfolder)

activities.name: Empty folder
activities.description: Remove all contents from a folderFor the function to work optimal, all files and subfolders in the main targetfolder should be closed.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Full path to the folder that will be emptied

parameters.name: allow_root
parameters.description: Allow paths with an arbitrary length of 10 characters or shorter to be emptied. Default value is False.

activities.example:
>>> # Make new folder in home directory for illustration
>>> testfolder = create_folder()
>>> # Make new textfile in this folder
>>> import os
>>> textfile_location = os.path.join(testfolder, 'testfile.txt')
>>> make_textfile(output_path=textfile_location )
>>> # Print all files in the testfolder
>>> print( get_files_in_folder(testfolder) ) # Should show 
>>> # Empty the folder
>>> empty_folder(testfolder)
>>> # Check what is in the folder
>>> get_files_in_folder(testfolder)
[]
activities.snippet:
# Make new folder in home directory for illustration
testfolder = create_folder()
# Make new textfile in this folder
import os
textfile_location = os.path.join(testfolder, 'testfile.txt')
make_textfile(output_path=textfile_location )
# Print all files in the testfolder
print( get_files_in_folder(testfolder) ) # Should show 
# Empty the folder
empty_folder(testfolder)
# Check what is in the folder
get_files_in_folder(testfolder)

activities.name: Checks if folder exists
activities.description: Check whether folder exists or not, regardless if folder is empty or not.

parameters.description: Full path to folder

>>> # Check if folder exists

activities.name: Copy a folder

parameters.description: Full path to the source location of the folder

parameters.name: new_path
parameters.description: Full path to the destination location of the folder. If no path is specified folder will get copied in the from_path directory

activities.return: Path to new folder as string

>>> testfolder = create_folder()

>>> # Since new_folder already exists in home dir this folder will get a random id added (in this case abc1)

activities.snippet:
# Make new folder in home directory for illustration
testfolder = create_folder()
# Copy this folder
# Since new_folder already exists in home dir this folder will get a random id added (in this case abc1)
copy_folder(testfolder)

activities.name: Zip
activities.description: Zia folder and it's contents. Creates a .zip file.

parameters.name: path

activities.name: Unzip

parameters.description: Full path to the source location of the file or folder that will be unzipped

parameters.name: to_path

>>> # Make new folder in home directory for illustration

activities.name: Return most recent file in directory
activities.description: Return most recent file in directory

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path which will be scanned for most recent file

activities.example:
>>> # Find most recent file in homedir
>>> most_recent_file(path=homedir())
activities.snippet:
# Find most recent file in homedir
most_recent_file(path=homedir())

activities.name: Wait
activities.description: Make the robot wait for a specified number of seconds. Note that this activity is blocking. This means that subsequent activities will not occur until the the specified waiting time has expired.

parameters.name: seconds
parameters.description: Time in seconds to wait

activities.example:
>>> print('Start the wait')
>>> wait()
>>> print('The wait is over')
activities.snippet:
print('Start the wait')
wait()
print('The wait is over')

activities.name: Wait for image
activities.description: Waits for an image to appear on the screenNote that this activity waits for an exact match of the template image to appear on the screen.Small variations, such as color or resolution could result in a mismatch.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Full or relative path to the template image.

parameters.name: timeout
parameters.description: Maximum time in seconds to wait before continuing. Default value is 60 seconds.

activities.example:
>>> # Create a random snippet from current screen
>>> # This is for illustration and can be replaced by template
>>> snippet = random_screen_snippet(size=10)
>>> # Wait for the snippet to be visible
>>> wait_for_image(snippet)
activities.snippet:
# Create a random snippet from current screen
# This is for illustration and can be replaced by template
snippet = random_screen_snippet(size=10)
# Wait for the snippet to be visible
wait_for_image(snippet)

activities.name: Wait for folder
activities.description: Waits until a folder exists.Not that this activity is blocking and will keep the system waiting.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Full path to folder.

parameters.name: timeout
parameters.description: Maximum time in seconds to wait before continuing. Default value is 60 seconds.

activities.example:
>>> # Create a random folder
>>> testfolder = create_folder()
>>> # Wait for the snippet to be visible
>>> wait_folder_exists(testfolder)
activities.snippet:
# Create a random folder
testfolder = create_folder()
# Wait for the snippet to be visible
wait_folder_exists(testfolder)

activities.name: Start Word Application
activities.description: For this activity to work, Microsoft Office Word needs to be installed on the system.

parameters.name: visible
parameters.description: Show Word in the foreground if True or hide if False, defaults to True.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Enter a path to open Word with an existing Word file. If no path is specified a document will be initialized, this is the default value.

activities.example: >>> word = Word()
activities.snippet: word = Word()

activities.name: Append text
activities.description: Append text at end of Word document.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to append to document

activities.example:
>>> # Start Word
>>> word = Word()
>>> word.append_text('This is sample text')
activities.snippet:
# Start Word
word = Word()
word.append_text('This is sample text')

activities.name: Replace text
activities.description: Can be used for example to replace arbitrary placeholder value. For example whenusing template document, using 'XXXX' as a placeholder. Take note that all strings are case sensitive.

parameters.name: placeholder_text
parameters.description: Placeholder text value (string) in the document, this will be replaced, e.g. 'Company Name'

parameters.name: replacement_text
parameters.description: Text (string) to replace the placeholder values with. It is recommended to make this unique to avoid wrongful replacement, e.g. 'XXXX_placeholder_XXX'

activities.example:
>>> # Start Word
>>> word = Word()
>>> word.append_text('This is sample text')
>>> word.replace_text('sample', 'real')
activities.snippet:
# Start Word
word = Word()
word.append_text('This is sample text')
word.replace_text('sample', 'real')

activities.name: Read all text
activities.description: Read all the text from a document

parameters.name: return_as_list
parameters.description: Set this paramater to True to return text as a list of strings. Default value is False.

activities.example:
>>> # Start Word
>>> word = Word()
>>> word.append_text('This is sample text')
>>> word.replace_text('sample', 'real')
>>> word.read_all_text()
'This is real text'
activities.snippet:
# Start Word
word = Word()
word.append_text('This is sample text')
word.replace_text('sample', 'real')
word.read_all_text()

activities.name: Export to PDF
activities.description: Export the document to PDF

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Output path where PDF file will be exported to. Default path is home directory with filename 'pdf_export.pdf'.

activities.example:
>>> # Start Word
>>> word = Word()
>>> word.append_text('This is sample text')
>>> word.replace_text('sample', 'real')
>>> word.export_to_pdf('output.pdf')
activities.snippet:
# Start Word
word = Word()
word.append_text('This is sample text')
word.replace_text('sample', 'real')
word.export_to_pdf('output.pdf')

activities.name: Export to HTML
activities.description: Export to HTML

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Output path where HTML file will be exported to. Default path is home directory with filename 'html_export.html'.

activities.example:
>>> # Start Word
>>> word = Word()
>>> word.append_text('This is sample text')
>>> word.replace_text('sample', 'real')
>>> word.export_to_html('output.html')
activities.snippet:
# Start Word
word = Word()
word.append_text('This is sample text')
word.replace_text('sample', 'real')
word.export_to_html('output.html')

activities.name: Set footers
activities.description: Set the footers of the document

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to put in the footer

activities.example:
>>> # Start Word
>>> word = Word()
>>> word.set_footers('This is a footer!')
activities.snippet:
# Start Word
word = Word()
word.set_footers('This is a footer!')

activities.name: Set headers
activities.description: Set the headers of the document

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to put in the header

activities.example:
>>> # Start Word
>>> word = Word()
>>> word.set_headers('This is a header!')
activities.snippet:
# Start Word
word = Word()
word.set_headers('This is a header!')

activities.name: Quit Word
activities.description: This closes Word, make sure to use 'save' or 'save_as' if you would like to save before quitting.
activities.example:
>>> # Open Word  
>>> word = Word()
>>> # Quit Word
>>> word.quit()
activities.snippet:
# Open Word  
word = Word()
# Quit Word
word.quit()

activities.name: Read and Write Word files
activities.description: These activities can read, write and edit Word (docx) files without the need of having Word installed.Note that, in contrary to working with the :func: 'Word' activities, a file get saved directly after manipulation.

parameters.name: file_path
parameters.description: Enter a path to open Word with an existing Word file. If no path is specified a 'document.docx' will be initialized in the home directory, this is the default value. If a document with the same name already exists the file will be overwritten.

activities.example:
>>> wordfile = WordFile()
>>> wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
>>> wordfile.read_all_text()
'Some sample text'
activities.snippet:
wordfile = WordFile()
wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
wordfile.read_all_text()

activities.name: Read all text
activities.description: Read all the text from the document

parameters.name: return_as_list
parameters.description: Set this paramater to True to return text as a list of strings. Default value is False.

activities.example:
>>> wordfile = WordFile()
>>> wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
>>> wordfile.read_all_text()
'Some sample text'
activities.snippet:
wordfile = WordFile()
wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
wordfile.read_all_text()

activities.name: Append text
activities.description: Append text at the end of the document

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to append

parameters.name: auto_save
parameters.description: Save document after performing activity. Default value is True

activities.example:
>>> wordfile = WordFile()
>>> wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
activities.snippet:
wordfile = WordFile()
wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')

activities.description: Save document
activities.example:
>>> wordfile = WordFile()
>>> wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
>>> wordfile.save()
activities.snippet:
wordfile = WordFile()
wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
wordfile.save()

activities.description: Save file on specified path
activities.example:
>>> wordfile = WordFile()
>>> wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
>>> wordfile.save_as('document.docx')
activities.snippet:

wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
wordfile.save_as('document.docx')

activities.name: Set headers
activities.description: Set headers of Word document

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to put in the header

parameters.name: auto_save

activities.example:
>>> wordfile = WordFile()
>>> wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
>>> wordfile.set_headers('This is a header')

activities.name: Replace all
activities.description: Replaces all occurences of a placeholder text in the document with a replacement text.

parameters.name: placeholder_text
parameters.description: Placeholder text value (string) in the document, this will be replaced, e.g. 'Company Name'

parameters.name: replacement_text
parameters.description: Text (string) to replace the placeholder values with. It is recommended to make this unique to avoid wrongful replacement, e.g. 'XXXX_placeholder_XXX'

parameters.name: auto_save
parameters.description: Save document after performing activity. Default value is True

activities.example:
>>> wordfile = WordFile()
>>> wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
>>> wordfile.replace_text('sample', 'real')
activities.snippet:
wordfile = WordFile()
wordfile.append_text('Some sample text')
wordfile.replace_text('sample', 'real')

activities.name: Start Outlook Application
activities.description: For this activity to work, Outlook needs to be installed on the system.
activities.example: >>> outlook = Outlook()
activities.snippet: outlook = Outlook()

activities.name: Send e-mail
activities.description: Send an e-mail using Outlook

parameters.name: to_address
parameters.description: The e-mail address the e-mail should be sent to

parameters.name: subject
parameters.description: The subject of the e-mail

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The text body contents of the e-mail

parameters.name: html_body
parameters.description: The HTML body contents of the e-mail (optional)

parameters.name: attachment_paths
parameters.description: List of file paths to attachments

activities.example:
>>> outlook = Outlook()
>>> outlook.send_mail('test@test.com', subject='Hello world', body='Hi there')
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.send_mail('test@test.com', subject='Hello world', body='Hi there')

activities.name: Retrieve folders
activities.description: Retrieve list of folders from Outlook

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Maximum number of folders to retrieve

activities.example:
>>> outlook = Outlook()
>>> outlook.get_folders()
['Inbox', 'Sent', ...]
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.get_folders()

activities.name: Retrieve e-mails
activities.description: Retrieve list of messages from Outlook

parameters.name: folder_name
parameters.description: Name of the Outlook folder, can be found using `get_folders`.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Number of messages to retrieve

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Fields (properties) of e-mail messages to give, requires tupl Stadard is 'Subject', 'Body', 'SentOn' and 'SenderEmailAddress'.

activities.return: List of dictionaries containing the e-mail messages with from, to, subject, body and html.
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.get_mails()
    {
        'Subject': 'Hello World!',
        'Body' : 'This is an e-mail',
        'SenderEmailAddress': 'from@test.com'
    }

activities.name: Delete e-mails
activities.description: Deletes e-mail messages in a certain folder. Can be specified by searching on subject, body or sender e-mail.

parameters.name: folder_name
parameters.description: Name of the Outlook folder, can be found using `get_folders`

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Maximum number of e-mails to delete in one go

parameters.name: subject_contains
parameters.description: Only delete e-mail if subject contains this

parameters.name: body_contains
parameters.description: Only delete e-mail if body contains this

parameters.name: sender_contains
parameters.description: Only delete e-mail if sender contains this

activities.example:
>>> outlook = Outlook()
>>> outlook.delete_mails(subject_contains='hello')
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.delete_mails(subject_contains='hello')

activities.name: Move e-mails
activities.description: Move e-mail messages in a certain folder. Can be specified by searching on subject, body or sender e-mail.

parameters.name: source_folder_name
parameters.description: Name of the Outlook source folder from where e-mails will be moved, can be found using `get_folders`

parameters.name: target_folder_name
parameters.description: Name of the Outlook destination folder to where e-mails will be moved, can be found using `get_folders`

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Maximum number of e-mails to move in one go

parameters.name: subject_contains
parameters.description: Only move e-mail if subject contains this

parameters.name: body_contains
parameters.description: Only move e-mail if body contains this

parameters.name: sender_contains
parameters.description: Only move e-mail if sender contains this

activities.example:
>>> outlook = Outlook()
>>> outlook.move_mails(subject_contains='move me')
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.move_mails(subject_contains='move me')

activities.name: Save attachments
activities.description: Save all attachments from certain folder

parameters.name: folder_name
parameters.description: Name of the Outlook folder, can be found using `get_folders`.

parameters.name: target_folder_path
parameters.description: Path where attachments will be saved. Default is the home directory.

activities.return: List of paths to saved attachments.
activities.example:
>>> outlook = Outlook()
>>> outlook.save_attachments()
['Attachment.pdf', 'Signature_image.jpeg']
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.save_attachments()

activities.name: Retrieve contacts
activities.description: Retrieve all contacts

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Fields can be specified as a tuple with their exact names. Standard value is None returning "LastName", "FirstName" and "Email1Address".

activities.return: List of dictionaries containing the contact details.
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.get_contacts()
    {
        'LastName': 'Doe',
        'FirstName' : 'John',
        'Email1Address': 'john@test.com'
    }

activities.name: Add a contact
activities.description: Add a contact to Outlook contacts

parameters.name: email
parameters.description: The e-mail address for the contact

parameters.name: first_name
parameters.description: First name for the contact (optional)

parameters.name: last_name
parameters.description: Last name for the contact (optional)

activities.example:
>>> outlook = Outlook()
>>> outlook.add_contact('sales@automagica.com')
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.add_contact('sales@automagica.com')

activities.name: Quit
activities.description: Close the Outlook application
activities.example:
>>> outlook = Outlook()
>>> outlook.quit()
activities.snippet:
outlook = Outlook()
outlook.quit()

activities.name: Start Excel Application
activities.description: For this activity to work, Microsoft Office Excel needs to be installed on the system.

parameters.name: visible
parameters.description: Show Excel in the foreground if True or hide if False, defaults to True.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Enter a path to open Excel with an existing Excel file. If no path is specified a workbook will be initialized, this is the default value.

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()

activities.name: Add worksheet
activities.description: Adds a worksheet to the current workbook

parameters.name: workbook
parameters.description: Workbook object which is retrieved with either new_workbook or open_workbook

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add a worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add a worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')

activities.name: Activate worksheet
activities.description: Activate a worksheet in the current Excel document by name

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Name of the worksheet to activate

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel   
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add the first worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Add another worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('Another Worksheet')
>>> # Activate the first worksheet
>>> excel.activate_worksheet('My Example Worksheet)
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel   
excel = Excel()
# Add the first worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Add another worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('Another Worksheet')
# Activate the first worksheet
excel.activate_worksheet('My Example Worksheet)

activities.name: Save
activities.description: Save the current workbook
activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add the first worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Save the workbook to My Documents
>>> excel.save()
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add the first worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Save the workbook to My Documents
excel.save()

activities.name: Save as
activities.description: Save the current workbook to a specific path

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path where workbook will be saved. Default is home directory and filename 'workbook.xlsx'

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add the first worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Save the workbook to the current working directory
>>> excel.save_as('output.xlsx')
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add the first worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Save the workbook to the current working directory
excel.save_as('output.xlsx')

activities.name: Write cell
activities.description: Write to a specific cell in the currently active workbook and active worksheet

parameters.name: column
parameters.description: Column number (integer) to write

parameters.name: row
parameters.description: Row number (integer) to write

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: Value to write to specific cell

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add the first worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Insert a text into the first cell
>>> excel.write_cell(1,1, 'Hello World!')
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add the first worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Insert a text into the first cell
excel.write_cell(1,1, 'Hello World!')

activities.name: Read cell
activities.description: Read a cell from the currently active workbook and active worksheet

parameters.name: column
parameters.description: Column number (integer) to read

parameters.name: row
parameters.description: Row number (integer) to read

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add the first worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Insert a text into the first cell
>>> excel.write_cell(1,1, 'Hello World!')
>>> excel.read_cell(1,1)
'Hello World!'
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add the first worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Insert a text into the first cell
excel.write_cell(1,1, 'Hello World!')
excel.read_cell(1,1)

activities.name: Write range
activities.description: Write to a specific range in the currently active worksheet in the active workbook

parameters.name: range_
parameters.description: Range to write to, e.g. "A1:D10"

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: Value to write to range

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add the first worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Insert a text in every cell in this range
>>> excel.write_range('A1:D5', 'Hello World!')
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add the first worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Insert a text in every cell in this range
excel.write_range('A1:D5', 'Hello World!')

activities.name: Read range
activities.description: Read a range of cells from the currently active worksheet in the active workbook

parameters.name: range_
parameters.description: Range to read from, e.g. "A1:D10"

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add the first worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Insert a text in every cell in this range
>>> excel.write_range('A1:D5', 'Hello World!')
>>> # Read the same range
>>> excel.read_range('A1:D5')
[['Hello World', 'Hello World', 'Hello World', 'Hello World'], ...]
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add the first worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Insert a text in every cell in this range
excel.write_range('A1:D5', 'Hello World!')
# Read the same range
excel.read_range('A1:D5')

activities.name: Run macro
activities.description: Run a macro by name from the currently active workbook

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Name of the macro to run.

activities.example:
>>> excel = Excel('excel_with_macro.xlsx')
>>> # Run the macro
>>> excel.run_macro('Macro1')
activities.snippet:
excel = Excel('excel_with_macro.xlsx')
# Run the macro
excel.run_macro('Macro1')

activities.name: Get worksheet names
activities.description: Get names of all the worksheets in the currently active workbook
activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Add a worksheet
>>> excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
>>> # Get all worksheet names
>>> excel.get_worksheet_names()
['Sheet1', 'My Example Worksheet']
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Add a worksheet
excel.add_worksheet('My Example Worksheet')
# Get all worksheet names
excel.get_worksheet_names()

activities.name: Get table
activities.description: Get table data from the currently active worksheet by name of the table

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: List of table names

activities.example:
>>> # Open Excel
>>> excel = Excel()
>>> # Create a table (Table1)
>>> data = [
    {
        'Column A': 'Data Row 1 for A',
        'Column B': 'Data Row 1 for B',
        'Column C': 'Data Row 1 for C',
    },
    {
        'Column A': 'Data Row 2 for A',
        'Column B': 'Data Row 2 for B',
        'Column C': 'Data Row 2 for C',
    }]
>>> excel.insert_data_as_table(data)
>>> # Get the table
>>> excel.get_table('Table1')
[['Column A', 'Column B', 'Column C'], ['Row 1 A Data', 'Row 1 B Data', 'Row 1 C Data'], ...]
activities.snippet:
# Open Excel
excel = Excel()
# Create a table (Table1)
data = [
    {
        'Column A': 'Data Row 1 for A',
        'Column B': 'Data Row 1 for B',
        'Column C': 'Data Row 1 for C',
    },
    {
        'Column A': 'Data Row 2 for A',
        'Column B': 'Data Row 2 for B',
        'Column C': 'Data Row 2 for C',
    }]
excel.insert_data_as_table(data)
# Get the table
excel.get_table('Table1')

activities.name: Replace all occurences of text in PowerPoint slides
activities.description: Can be used for example to replace arbitrary placeholder value in a PowerPoint.For example when using a template slidedeck, using 'XXXX' as a placeholder.Take note that all strings are case sensitive.

parameters.name: placeholder_text
parameters.description: Placeholder value (string) in the PowerPoint, this will be replaced, e.g. 'Company Name'

parameters.name: replacement_text
parameters.description: Text (string) to replace the placeholder values with. It is recommended to make this unique in your PowerPoint to avoid wrongful replacement, e.g. 'XXXX_placeholder_XXX'

activities.example:
>>> # Start PowerPoint
>>> powerpoint = PowerPoint()
>>> # Add some slides with text
>>> powerpoint.add_text(text='Hello, my name is placeholder')
>>> # Change 'placeholder' to the word 'robot
>>> powerpoint.replace_text(placeholder_text = 'placeholder', replacement_text ='robot')
activities.snippet:
# Start PowerPoint
powerpoint = PowerPoint()
# Add some slides with text
powerpoint.add_text(text='Hello, my name is placeholder')
# Change 'placeholder' to the word 'robot
powerpoint.replace_text(placeholder_text = 'placeholder', replacement_text ='robot')

parameters.description: Determines if only logical units are added to the count, default value is True.

activities.example:
>>> get_number_of_cpu()
2
activities.snippet: get_number_of_cpu()

activities.name: CPU frequency
activities.description: Get frequency at which CPU currently operates.
activities.example:
>>> get_cpu_frequency()
scpufreq(current=3600.0, min=0.0, max=3600.0)
activities.snippet: get_cpu_frequency()

activities.name: CPU Stats
activities.description: Get CPU statistics
activities.return: Number of CTX switches, intterupts, soft-interrupts and systemcalls.
activities.example:
>>> get_cpu_stats()
scpustats(ctx_switches=735743826, interrupts=1540483897, soft_interrupts=0, syscalls=2060595131)
activities.snippet: get_cpu_stats()

activities.name: Memory statistics
activities.description: Get  memory statistics

parameters.name: mem_type
parameters.description: Choose mem_type = 'virtual' for virtual memory, and mem_type = 'swap' for swap memory (standard).

activities.return: Total, used, free and percentage in use.
activities.example:
>>> get_memory_stats()
sswap(total=24640016384, used=18120818688, free=6519197696, percent=73.5, sin=0, sout=0)
activities.snippet: get_memory_stats()

activities.name: Disk stats
activities.description: Get disk statistics of main disk
activities.return: Total, used, free and percentage in use.
activities.example:
>>> get_disk_stats()
sdiskusage(total=999559262208, used=748696350720, free=250862911488, percent=74.9)
activities.snippet: get_disk_stats()

activities.name: Partition info
activities.description: Get disk partition info
activities.return: tuple with info for every partition.
activities.example:
>>> get_disk_paritions()
[sdiskpart(device='C:\\', mountpoint='C:\\', fstype='NTFS', opts='rw,fixed')]
activities.snippet: get_disk_paritions()

activities.name: Boot time
activities.description: Get most recent boot time
activities.return: time PC was booted in seconds after the epoch.
activities.snippet: get_boot_time()

activities.name: Uptime
activities.description: Get uptime since last boot
activities.return: time since last boot in seconds.
activities.example:
>>> get_time_since_last_boot()
1337.0
activities.snippet: get_time_since_last_boot()

activities.name: Windows run

# Open home directory with Windows run

activities.name: Get text with OCR
activities.description: This activity extracts all text from the current screen or an image if a path is specified.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path to image from where text will be extracted. If no path is specified a screenshot of current screen will be used.

activities.return: String with all text from current screen
activities.example:
>>> # Make a textfile with some text to recognize
>>> testfile = make_textfile(text='OCR Example')
>>> # Open the textfile
>>> open_file(testfile)
>>> # Find the text with OCR
>>> extracted_text = find_text_on_screen_ocr(text='OCR Example')
>>> # Check if the extracted_text contains the original word
>>> 'OCR Example' in extracted_text
True
activities.snippet:
# Make a textfile with some text to recognize
testfile = make_textfile(text='OCR Example')
# Open the textfile
open_file(testfile)
# Find the text with OCR
extracted_text = find_text_on_screen_ocr(text='OCR Example')
# Check if the extracted_text contains the original word
'OCR Example' in extracted_text

activities.name: Find text on screen with OCR
activities.description: This activity finds position (coordinates) of specified text on the current screen using OCR.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to find. Only exact matches are returned.

parameters.name: criteria
parameters.description: Criteria to select on if multiple matches are found. If no criteria is specified all matches will be returned. Options are 'first', which returns the first match closest to the upper left corner, 'last' returns the last match closest to the lower right corner, random selects a random match.

activities.return: Dictionary or list of dictionaries with matches with following elements: 'h' height in pixels, 'text' the matched text,'w' the width in pixels, 'x' absolute x-coördinate , 'y' absolute y-coördinate. Returns nothing if no matches are found
activities.example:
>>> # Make a textfile with some text to recognize
>>> testfile = make_textfile(text='OCR Example')
>>> # Open the textfile
>>> open_file(testfile)
>>> # Find the text with OCR
>>> find_text_on_screen_ocr(text='OCR Example')
activities.snippet:
# Make a textfile with some text to recognize
testfile = make_textfile(text='OCR Example')
# Open the textfile
open_file(testfile)
# Find the text with OCR
find_text_on_screen_ocr(text='OCR Example')

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: Text to find. Only exact matches are returned.

activities.example:
>>> # Make a textfile with some text to recognize
>>> testfile = make_textfile(text='OCR Example')
>>> # Open the textfile
>>> open_file(testfile)
>>> # Find the text with OCR and click on it

activities.snippet:

testfile = make_textfile(text='OCR Example')
# Open the textfile
open_file(testfile)
# Find the text with OCR and click on it
click_on_text_ocr(text='OCR Example')

activities.name: Execute a UiPath process
activities.description: This activity allows you to execute a process designed with the UiPath Studio. All console output from the Write Line activity (https://docs.uipath.com/activities/docs/write-line) will be printed as output.

parameters.name: project_file_path
parameters.description: path to the project file (as created within the UiPath Studio)

parameters.name: arguments
parameters.description: dictionary with input arguments/parameters for the process to use in UiPath (optional)

parameters.name: uirobot_exe_path
parameters.description: path to UiPath's UiRobot.exe (optional)

activities.example:
>>> # Run a UiPath process
>>> arguments = {'firstname': 'John', 'lastname': 'Doe'}
>>> execute_uipath_process(r"C:\Processes UiPath\my_process.xaml", arguments=arguments)
Completed UiPath process "C:\Processes UiPath\my_process.xaml"

activities.name: Execute a AutoIt script
activities.description: This activity allows you to run an AutoIt script. If you use the ConsoleWrite function (https://www.autoitscript.com/autoit3/docs/functions/ConsoleWrite.htm), the output will be presented to you.

parameters.name: script_path
parameters.description: path to the '.au3' script file

parameters.name: arguments
parameters.description: string with input arguments/parameters for the script (optional)

parameters.name: autoit_exe_path
parameters.description: path to AutoIt.exe (optional)

activities.example:
>>> # Run an AutoIt script
>>> arguments = 'John'
>>> run_autoit_script(r"C:\AutoIt\Scripts\MyScript.au3", arguments=arguments) # Point this to your AutoIt Script
Completed AutoIt script "C:\AutoIt\Scripts\MyScript.au3"
activities.snippet:
# Run an AutoIt script
arguments = 'John'
run_autoit_script(r"C:\AutoIt\Scripts\MyScript.au3", arguments=arguments) # Point this to your AutoIt Script

activities.name: Execute a Robot Framework test case
activities.description: This activity allows you to run a Robot Framework test case. Console output of the test case will be printed.

parameters.name: test_case_path
parameters.description: path to the '.robot' test case file

parameters.name: variables
parameters.description: dictionary with variable declarations

activities.example:
>>> # Run an Robot Framework test case
>>> variables = {'FIRSTNAME': 'John', 'LASTNAME': 'Doe'}
>>> execute_robotframework_test(r"C:\Test Cases\my_test_case.robot", variables=variables) # Point this to your Robot Framework test case
Completed Robot Framework test case "C:\Test Cases\my_test_case.robot"

activities.function_call: run_blueprism_process(process_name, username='', password='', sso=False, inputs=None, automatec_exe_path=None)
activities.name: Run a Blue Prism process
activities.description: This activity allows you to run a Blue Prism process.

parameters.name: process_name
parameters.description: name of the process in Blue Prism

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Blue Prism username

activities.name: Create a new job in the Automagica Portal

>>> # Create a job in the Automagica Portal

Job 1234567890 created

activities.name: Check if element is visible on screen

>>> is_visible('abc123abc123')
activities.snippet:

recorder()
# Use ID to perform visibility check
is_visible('abc123abc123')

activities.name: Detect and click on an element with the Automagica Vision API
activities.description: This activity allows the bot to detect and click on an element by using the Automagica Vision API with a provided sample ID.

parameters.name: element_id
parameters.description: the sample ID provided by the Vision Recorder

activities.example:
>>> # Record an element to read
>>> recorder()
>>> Read the text in the element
>>> text = read_text('abc123abc123')
activities.snippet:
# Record an element to read
recorder()
Read the text in the element
text = read_text('abc123abc123')
